name: Al Jazari Institute
mission: To provide quality Islamic education to our students while instilling in them Islamic character, morals, and ethics.
theoryOfChange: Providing intensive Islamic education and detailed progress reporting to instill Islamic character, morals, and ethics in students to nurture future leaders.
zakatClaimEvidence: The search results for the US-based Al Jazari Institute (located in Minneapolis, MN) describe its mission as providing Islamic educational services, including Quranic studies and Arabic language training. There is no explicit mention of 'zakat' on their website or donation pages, nor any dedicated zakat funds or campaigns for the US entity in the provided snippets. While a 'Jazari' entity in the UK explicitly mentions 'Zakat Payment Options', this is an international affiliate and does not apply to the US organization. (Source: https://www.charitynavigator.org/ein/455134951#financials)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Good donor alignment with manageable risk. Evidence quality is solid but still evolving in places.

components.evidence: Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: fi_sabilillah (+5)
components.improvement_suggestion: Add a dedicated zakat page or clearly state whether donations are zakat-eligible.

alignment.rationale: Alignment 31/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, education global cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring; moderate program ratio (≥65%)
components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.

There is no explicit mention of 'zakat' on their website or donation pages, nor any dedicated zakat funds or campaigns for the US entity in the provided snippets. While a 'Jazari' entity in the UK explicitly mentions 'Zakat Payment Options', this is an international affiliate and does not apply to the US organization. all_citations.claim: The organization offers Islamic education and civic engagement programs including Qur'anic and Islamic Sciences.
The organization reported total revenue of $2,997,604, a program expense ratio of 68.6%, fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised, and 3.0 months of working capital.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization receives a moderate score due to its established educational programs and efficient fundraising, though its overall financial health is constrained by lower program spending ratios and limited liquidity.
areas_for_improvement: Program expense ratio is below the industry-standard benchmark of 75%
Limited working capital reserves for long-term sustainability

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization shows a medium alignment for donors interested in global education, specifically within the niche of traditional Islamic sciences [1]. As a sadaqah-eligible entity, it serves as a relevant pathway for general charitable giving, though its specific track record and data confidence remain at a medium level [1][2].
dimension_explanations.impact: The institute demonstrates a moderate impact through its capacity-building model, allocating a 68.6% program expense ratio toward Islamic and Qur'anic science initiatives [1][2]. While the organization successfully generates significant revenue, it holds 3.0 months of working capital, suggesting a need for stronger cash reserves to ensure long-term program stability [2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The AL Jazari Institute provides comprehensive Islamic education and civic engagement programs to empower individuals and families within the community.
strengths: High fundraising efficiency with only $0.09 spent to raise every $1
Dedicated programming for both Qur'anic and Islamic Sciences
baseline_narrative.summary: The AL Jazari Institute is a non-profit organization dedicated to offering specialized instruction in Qur'anic and Islamic Sciences alongside community-focused civic programs [1]. In the 2023 fiscal year, the institute reported a total revenue of $2,997,604 to support its educational mission [2].

confidence.data_freshness: Financial data current through 2023 tax year
confidence.notes: Financial data is robust, but impact and governance transparency are limited.

alignment.explanation: The organization aligns with Muslim donor interests by focusing on <cite id="2">Islamic Sciences and Qur'anic education</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Clearly state the <cite id="16">intended use of sadaqah funds</cite> and whether any programs are eligible for specific categories of giving.

credibility.explanation: The institute maintains credibility through <cite id="10">100% independent board members</cite> and consistent <cite id="3">financial reporting via Form 990</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should expand its board size and publish audited financial statements to the public.

giving_considerations: Donations support an organization in a high-growth phase

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a verified theory of change but a lack of public beneficiary data or external impact evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The institute uses specialized Islamic instruction to build community capacity and civic engagement.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that educational programs are effectively transferring knowledge and achieving civic goals.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: Rapid revenue growth and expanding programs suggest a high capacity to absorb new capital for educational infrastructure.

strengths.detail: The institute demonstrates high fiscal discipline in its development efforts, spending only <cite id="8">$0.09 per $1 raised</cite>.
The organization has achieved a <cite id="4">3-year revenue CAGR of 22.6%</cite>, indicating increasing community support and scale.
The charity successfully balances <cite id="5">$1.58 million in donations</cite> with <cite id="6">$1.38 million in program service revenue</cite>.

strengths_deep_dive: The AL Jazari Institute's primary strength lies in its ability to scale its educational mission rapidly while maintaining low fundraising costs. With a <cite id="4">revenue CAGR of 22.6%</cite>, the organization is moving from a growth stage toward becoming an established institution. Its financial resilience is supported by <cite id="11">3.0 months of working capital</cite>, which provides a buffer for its <cite id="12">$3.16 million in annual expenses</cite>. Furthermore, the institute's commitment to transparency is evidenced by its <cite id="13">documented theory of change</cite>, which helps align its educational outputs with community outcomes.
rich_narrative.summary: The AL Jazari Institute is a non-profit educational organization dedicated to providing <cite id="1">specialized instruction in Qur'anic and Islamic Sciences</cite> alongside community-focused civic engagement programs. Operating primarily within the United States, the institute serves as a hub for capacity building through <cite id="2">Arabic language programs and Islamic studies</cite>. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported <cite id="3">total revenue of $2,997,604</cite>, representing a significant <cite id="4">three-year revenue growth rate of 22.6%</cite>. The institute's financial model is diversified, drawing <cite id="5">$1,586,418 from public contributions</cite> and <cite id="6">$1,389,723 from program service revenue</cite>, which suggests a sustainable earned-income component to its educational offerings. While the organization maintains <cite id="7">high fundraising efficiency</cite>, spending only <cite id="8">$0.09 to raise every $1</cite>, its overall financial health is characterized by a <cite id="9">program expense ratio of 68.6%</cite>. This indicates that while the mission is clearly defined, a substantial portion of the budget is currently directed toward administrative and growth-related costs. The institute's governance is marked by an <cite id="10">independent board of directors</cite>, ensuring oversight of its mission to empower individuals and families through faith-based education.
